Class Arena

  • java.lang.Object
    • greenfoot.World
      • Arena

  • public class Arena
extends greenfoot.World
    This creates the game Arena in which the game play occurs, along with the various obstacles
    Version:
    May 5, 2016
    Author:
    Kevin Ge Some methods were completed by other groups members and are mentioned under each respective methods

    • Constructor Detail

      • Arena

        public Arena()
        Constructor for the Arena. Sets world size to 1200 by 1200. Direction of runner and gamestate set to 0. Kevin Ge

    • Method Detail

      • act

        public void act()
        Game screens and main code. Game state 0 - Title screen Game state 1 - Game initialization. Runner "snake" is created. Bricks are spawned and timer started. Game state -1 - Gameover. High scores recorded in LinkedList of integers. All objects are removed. Otherwise continuously runs snake movement and enemy spawning. Kevin Ge
        Overrides:
        act in class greenfoot.World

      • setGameState

        public void setGameState(int state)
        Method to change game state. Mainly used to end the game from other classes (ex. brick and enemy) Kevin Ge

      • killedEnemy

        public void killedEnemy()
        Called by enemy when enemy dies. Decreases numEnemies to allow for more spawning. Kevin Ge

      • getTimer

        public Timer getTimer()
        Returns the timer for other classes to use world's time.
        Returns:
        world's timer Kevin Ge

      • scores

        public void scores()
        Calculates scores with insertion sort By David Magnusson

      • addLabel

        public void addLabel(int score,
            int x,
            int y)
        Adds labels (text) for final high score screen
        Parameters:
        score - given score
        x - location x
        y - location y David Magnusson

      • addBrick

        public void addBrick(int x,
            int y)
        Helper method for spawnBricks(). Allows to create multiple bricks without naming them individually.
        Parameters:
        x - location x
        y - location y Lawrence Cheng
